In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) supports the priority given by the Government of 
the Philippines to achieving high-quality universal basic education. In 2009, the government 
confirmed  its  request  for  technical  assistance  (TA)  for  the  Computer  Access  Mentorship 
Program  (CAMP)—a  Public–Private  Partnership  for  Enhancing  Education  Quality. 1  An 
understanding with the government has been reached on the goals, purpose, outputs, scope, 
implementation arrangements, costs, financing arrangements, and outline terms of reference for 
the consultants. The design and monitoring framework for the TA is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  The Philippine Medium-Term Development Plan 2004–2010 identifies the achieving of 
universal basic education as a major goal of both the National Education for All 2015 Plan and 
the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs). However, despite good progress in the 1990s and 
a continuing high level of commitment, it appears that the government will have difficulty in 
meeting  the  MDG  target  of  universal  access  to  basic  education  by  2015.  Key  education 
indicators are worsening through increasing dropout levels and lowering academic attainment, 
which translate ultimately into higher levels of joblessness and poverty. 
 
3.  The  latest  country  strategy  and  program  for  the  Philippines  2005–20072 promotes 
synergies between the public and private sectors, both because private sector operations can 
have a catalytic effect upon the public sector, and because the pressure on public resources is 
reduced.3 Education, while not a feature of the country strategy and program, is expected to 
play a more significant role in the future (country operations business plan 2010–2012). The 
proposed project is a good example of a public–private partnership, in which private resources 
and talents are harnessed by two civil society organizations (CSOs) in a concerted effort to 
support the public education system and improve the quality of teaching and learning.   
 
4.  Government policy. In 2001, the Governance of Basic Education Act (Republic Act No. 
9155) was passed, which stressed decentralization of education management and placed the 
school at the center of reforms to improve the quality of basic education. These reforms were 
further  developed  and  implemented  in  secondary  schools  through  the  ADB-supported 
Secondary Education Development and Improvement Project.4 By 2005 there was widespread 
consensus on the need for urgent sectorwide strategies that would place schools first and 
empower  local  communities  to  achieve  school  improvement.  This  consensus  has  been 
articulated into the Philippine Basic Education Sector Reform Agenda (BESRA). The overall 
objectives  of  BESRA  encompass  universal  access  to  basic  education  and  its  successful 
completion. The five key reform thrusts are (i) continuous school improvement through active 
involvement  of  local  stakeholders;  (ii)  better  learning  outcomes  through  improved  teacher 
standards;  (iii)  learning  outcomes  enhanced  by  national  curriculum  strategies,  multisector 
coordination, and quality assurance; (iv) improved outcomes resulting from complementary 
learning systems, and private sector participation; and (v) a change in the Department of 
Education  culture  from  prescribing  actions  through  directives  to  facilitating  school-based 
initiatives and assuring quality.

5.  Department of Education policy actively encourages partnerships with civil society and 
private sector organizations to meet these goals. As a result, there is an impressive array of 
societies of educators, civil organizations, and business groups playing a prominent role in 
supporting government efforts to achieve universal access and raise quality. Corporate social 
responsibility efforts are now well organized under one umbrella organization. Other smaller 
groups have developed programs to address specific critical issues. One such group is the Sa 
Aklat  Sisikat  (SAS)  Foundation  which  has  successfully  promoted  reading  among  tens  of 
thousands of children over the last decade in an effective school-based program. However, the 
impact of the program is constrained by the absence of longer term, ongoing reinforcement of 
teacher skills once each school program finishes. A more broad-based approach able to reach 
larger numbers of teachers is needed.  
 
6.  Primary education system. National trends reveal a decline in education access and 
education quality. National primary net enrolment rates, for example, decreased by 6.5% between 
2002–2003 and 2006–2007 (from 90% to 84%), and completion rates decreased by 4.8% (from 
72% to 68%).5 When the national figures are disaggregated to focus on the poorest provinces, 
increasing inequality is evident. The basic education system as a whole is critically overburdened 
and dangerously under-resourced. The Government of the Philippines spends on education, on 
average,  one  tenth  of  what  is  spent  in  neighboring  countries.  In  2008,  the  national  budget 
allocated P128 billion to basic education, 90% of which was spent on salaries and benefits. The 
remaining 10% is too little to support quality improvement. Of the 1.4 million grade 6 elementary 
students who took the High School Readiness Examination in 2004, less than 1% managed a 
passing score in mathematics, English, and science subjects. In the same year, only 2% of high 
school students achieved a passing score. It is widely acknowledged that poor reading skills play 
a major role in this failure. With little motivation to learn, a high 33% of elementary school students 
drop out before they even reach high school.  
 
7.  Teacher quality. Better teacher quality is key to improving student learning outcomes. 
This  is  recognized  by  BESRA,  which  places  improved  teacher  standards  among  its  top 
priorities.  Unfortunately,  most  public  school  teachers  are  ill-equipped  to  overcome  the 
challenges  presented  to  them.  To  begin  with,  the  training  and  professional  development 
opportunities available to most public school teachers both during their formal education and 
while on the job are largely inadequate. Many public school teachers receive a substandard 
education. While employed in the schools—particularly in rural and other marginalized areas—
these teachers have few opportunities for professional development. Thus, year after year, 
teachers continue to use outdated, ineffective teaching methods that fail to capture the attention 
and imagination of their students. 
 
8.  Overcrowding requires schools to operate in shifts, leaving teachers overworked and 
struggling to balance their work and family responsibilities. Despite their hard work, teacher 
salaries are low and their take-home pay even lower. Most require a second income and 
consequently do not have the time or money for further studies. Many public school teachers 
are also the sole earners in their households, which is an added source of stress. With so few 
resources, the public school system can be a disempowering environment. With little support 
from administrators and hardworking parents, few teachers feel motivated enough to invest 
extra time and energy in training that might go unrecognized and unrewarded. Many of the 
country’s best-trained teachers move abroad. 
 
9.  Lessons learned. Gearing Up Internet Literacy and Access for Students is a major 
project of the Department of Education that aims to bring internet connectivity to all of the

country's 6,400 public high schools. This project also trains teachers from connected schools so 
that they will be able to maximize the internet as a resource for students and care properly for 
computers. The SAS CAMP project will complement this initiative. All major e-learning initiatives 
that have been piloted by the Department of Education and other agencies will be assessed by 
the SAS at the start of TA implementation, to ensure that the key lessons learned are applied in 
the design of the program. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
10.  The project will help improve basic education by developing an innovative strategy for 
improving education quality. In particular, the project will address what is widely recognized as a 
fundamental weakness among Philippine students—poor reading skills. The underresourcing of 
basic education, combined with the high population growth rate, has resulted in a crisis of 
quality which has not been addressed successfully through conventional approaches. Funds for 
the in-service training of teachers have been severely restricted. A new approach to in-service 
training  is  needed  that  will  strengthen  existing  skills  and  expose  teachers  to  the  latest 
developments in teaching. To reach large numbers of teachers who cannot afford to travel and 
who are dispersed over a wide geographic area, the project will develop and provide access to 
an information and communication technology (ICT)-based training program to improve the 
teaching of reading. This will be undertaken through a new and innovative partnership between 
two established CSOs—SAS and the Boy Scouts of the Philippines (BSP). The program will be 
an extension of the current SAS program which improves reading skills through face-to-face 
training of teachers. This will be expanded into an online training model. The BSP is a highly 
successful CSO, with 2 million members (the largest scouts movement in the world), 109 
councils, and a close relationship with the public school system through its more than 100,000 
scout leaders, most of whom are teachers or principals. It also has a well-established network of 
council offices, generally located close to elementary schools.  
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
11.  The  expected  impact  is  improved  learning  outcomes,  especially  in  reading,  among 
elementary students covered by the project sites. The expected outcome is a replicable and 
sustainable  ICT-based  in-service  training  program  that  enhances  elementary  teacher 
competencies in the teaching of reading, by mid-2013.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  The proposed project will build 50 CAMP sites over a period of 3 years, in three phases 
covering sites in Manila, Northern Luzon, and Visayas and Mindanao. These CAMP sites will 
serve as a place for elementary school teachers to learn new and innovative teaching methods 
through the development of (i) online teacher training, (ii) online teaching aids, and (iii) teacher 
manuals. The program’s desired  multiplier effect  will later spread these new approaches to 
teaching to fellow instructors and, ultimately, to students. The focus of the project will be reading 
skills, which have been identified as the fundamental cause of the weak learning outcomes so 
widely observed among Filipino students.  
 
13.  The online program will be based on the training program currently offered by SAS in the 
teaching of reading to public school elementary teachers. Training modules and materials will be 
developed for online strengthening of teaching skills and teacher competences in reading. The 
program will consist of around 20 hours of instruction, and it is expected that teachers will complete 
the program within 1 month. The program will introduce reading theories, principles, and how to 
translate  these  into  the  classroom,  and  will  cover  student-centered  and  literature-based 
approaches to the teaching of reading.

4   
14.  The Department of Education has demonstrated its support for the project through a 
memorandum of understanding with SAS. The current SAS training materials and program will 
be used as the starting point for the online training modules, though SAS recognizes that 
significant  adaptation  will  be  required  for  the  online  medium.  A  second  memorandum  of 
understanding will be signed with the Department of Education to recognize completion of the 
online training program as part of teachers' annual in-service credits.   
 
15.  The CAMP sites will support focused training to enable scout leaders and teachers to 
exploit ICT-based access to information, materials, and networks in adopting pupil-centered and 
active learning approaches. To ensure the retention of skills and links to actual practice, face-to-
face training in the BSP council sites will be conducted twice a year. Training-of-trainers will 
prepare three mobile teams to conduct training and basic monitoring. The expected outputs are 
as follows: 
 
1.  Increased  Access  to  Online  Training  Opportunities  in  Reading  for 
Elementary Teachers 
16.   The TA will expand access to online in-service training by establishing a nationwide 
network of 50 training facilities through which elementary teachers will be able to complete an 
online training course on the teaching of reading. The TA will provide 150 computers for 50 
CAMP sites.6 As the sites selected are near elementary schools, all teachers will have easy 
access. Schedules for use of the computers will be established to optimize the number of 
teachers undertaking the online training.  
 
2.  Training  Modules  and  Materials  Developed  for  Online  Strengthening  of 
Teaching Skills in Reading 
17.  The  TA  will  develop  an  online,  modularized  program  consisting  of  animated  and 
interactive training modules and materials, based on the successful SAS teaching of reading 
curriculum for elementary teachers. Each module will finish with self-evaluation questions.  
 
3.  Improved Knowledge among Teachers of Student-Centered Approaches to 
the Teaching of Reading 
18.  The  combination  of  a  new  online  teaching  reading  curriculum,  increased  access  to 
computers, and a managed training schedule is expected to enable 12,000 elementary teachers to 
complete in-service reading training online. The program emphasizes student-centered teaching as 
the most effective approach for the teaching of reading. It is expected that knowledge of student-
centered approaches among teachers will increase by 75%. Successful completion of the overall 
program will be measured through a final assessment that will be taken online. Certificates will be 
awarded to those who pass. 
 
4.  Monitoring and Evaluation System Established  
19.  A  comprehensive  monitoring  and  evaluation  system  will  be  developed  to  track  the 
progress  of  the  teachers  as  they  complete  the  program  and  record  the  completion  rate. 
Systematic monitoring and evaluation to generate key lessons learned will be carried out by 
SAS. They will also institute a strategy for automated tracking of ICT tool usage to provide 
information on how ICT tools are being used and where improvements are needed. Finally, 
school visits for training and evaluation will be used to collect examples of grassroots innovation, 
via video camera and other means, for compilation and dissemination to other public schools.  
                                                 
6  Each BSP training room will be equipped with four computers. The Government of the Republic of Korea has 
donated 50 refurbished computers to the Philippines, which will supplement the computers to be purchased under 
the TA.

5
 
20.  An  evaluation  study  will  be  carried  out  by  an  independent  agency  to  assess  the 
effectiveness of the online training program. The study will include a baseline and impact study, 
covering up to 50 project schools and an additional control sample. The results of the training 
program will be disseminated in collaboration with the ADB Institute. 
 
21.  The sustainability of the project is likely, given the strong commitment of both SAS and 
BSP, and the broad opportunities for eliciting funding given the high level of corporate and private 
donations to education in the Philippines. The project can be replicated without difficulty. Once the 
teachers  at  one  site  are  trained,  the  equipment  can  be  transferred  easily  to  another  site. 
Furthermore, the program can be adopted by any other CSO or corporate group once success is 
demonstrated. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
22.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $632,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on 
a grant basis by the Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund for the amount 
of $500,000. The grant will be administered by ADB. SAS will provide $132,000 in in-kind 
contributions. The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
23.  ADB will be the executing agency. SAS will implement the TA through a partnership 
agreement with ADB. SAS, a registered nongovernment organization, has been involved in 
upgrading the skills of public elementary teachers in the teaching of reading since 1999. In 
collaboration with other reputable educational institutions, SAS has created a curriculum that is 
culturally sensitive and appropriate, and has developed a high-quality cadre of trainers who will 
support program implementation. The TA will extend the SAS face-to-face training model into an 
online model that will enable more teachers to benefit from the SAS training program. 
 
24.  SAS  will  collaborate  with  the  BSP  in  TA  implementation,  as  specified  in  the 
memorandum of agreement signed on 6 January 2010 by the Department of Education, SAS, 
and BSP. A CAMP site administrator assigned by BSP will manage each CAMP site, with the 
costs  of  running  the  training  facility,  including  the  internet  connection  and  computer 
maintenance,  paid  by  BSP.  The  equipment  to  be  procured  will  include  computers  and 
peripherals. All equipment will be procured in accordance with ADB's Procurement Guidelines 
(2007, as amended from time to time), and will be retained by BSP after the TA ends so that the 
training program may continue and be replicated elsewhere. The teachers undertaking the 
training will pay a minimal amount to contribute to the cost of the internet connection. A contract 
will  later  be  signed  between  SAS  and  BSP  to  specify  the  operational  arrangements  and 
obligations in more detail. All disbursements will be made in accordance with ADB's Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook.7 
 
25.  SAS will establish a project implementation unit to oversee day-to-day implementation, 
including  procurement,  disbursement,  reporting,  and  information  collection.  The  project 
implementation unit will consist of a SAS project manager who will report to the SAS executive 
director and be responsible for day-to-day implementation, and a project assistant. SAS will 
engage four individual specialists: (i) an e-learning specialist to identify key lessons learned in 
previous online programs, (ii) an instructional developer to develop the online program, (iii) an ICT 
consultant to develop the software and web-based applications, and (iv) a reading specialist to 
support  the  development  and  implementation  of  the  reading  program.  An  institution  will  be

engaged to design the monitoring and evaluation system and carry out a baseline and impact 
study. 
 
26.  A committee representing the Department of Education’s Teacher Training Department, a 
reading expert engaged by SAS, the three partner educational institutions, and a representative of 
BSP will provide overall guidance and ensure linkages to national planning and policy dialogue.  
 
27.  SAS will provide four reports based on the following payment milestones: an inception 
report (35%), a report on the design of the training program at the end of year 1 and baseline 
survey (35%), a report on the implementation in the first 15 CAMP sites at the end of year 2 (25%), 
and submission of final report and final impact assessment (5%). In addition, SAS will provide 
short 3-montly reports for continuous monitoring by ADB. The TA will be implemented from 1 May 
2010 to 30 April 2013. 
  
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
28.  The  President,  acting  under  the  authority  delegated  by  the  Board,  has  approved 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 to be financed on a 
grant basis from the Government of Korea Computer Access Mentorship Program—a Public–
Private Partnership for Enhancing Education Quality, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Appendix 3  11 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR SA AKLAT SISIKAT FOUNDATION FOR THE 
COMPUTER ACCESS AND MENTORSHIP PROGRAM SITE PROJECT 
 
A.   Objectives 
 
1.  The proposed project will be implemented by the Sa Aklat Sisikat (SAS) Foundation in 
coordination  with  the  Boy  Scouts  Association  of  the  Philippines  (BSP),  under  a  partnership 
agreement  with  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB).  SAS  will  build  50  Computer  Access 
Mentorship Program (CAMP) sites over a period of 3 years. These CAMP sites will serve as a 
venue for elementary school teachers to learn new and innovative teaching methods through 
online in-service training aimed specifically at the improvement of teachers' skills in the teaching 
of reading. This program’s desired multiplier effect will then spread these new approaches to 
teaching to fellow instructors and, of course, ultimately, to students. Weak reading skills have 
been identified as the fundamental cause of the weak learning outcomes so widely observed 
among Filipino students.  
 
B.  Scope of the Work  
 
2.  The project is national in scope, covering the three major geographical areas of the 
Philippines: Luzon, Visayas, and Mindanao. The project will develop and deliver an online 
training program in the teaching of reading through the development of (i) online teacher training, 
(ii) online teaching aids, and (iii) teachers’ manuals.  
 
3.  The following are the major activities and outputs of the project: 
 
(i)  Establishment of 50 CAMP sites in selected BSP council offices with computers 
and internet. 
(ii)  Development  of  online  training  on  the  teaching  of  reading  for  public  school 
teachers, based on SAS’s face-to-face teacher training curriculum. 
(iii)  Development  of  an  online  teacher  training  system  that  is  accessible,  user- 
friendly, and recognized by the Department of Education. 
(iv)  Improvement  of  teaching  skills  in  reading  so  that  students  will  have  better 
reading skills and comprehension, with greater capacity to learn. 
(v)  Monitoring reports on the teachers’ use of the strategies learned when teaching 
reading in their classrooms. 
(vi)  An independent evaluation of the effectiveness of the online teacher training.  
 
C.  Detailed Tasks 
 
4.  The SAS will implement this project in coordination with the BSP. Specifically, the SAS 
will undertake the following: 
 
(i)  Establish a project implementation unit, including a project manager and project 
assistant to oversee and implement the project.  
(ii)  Review previous e-learning pilots and projects in the Philippines and elsewhere, 
to draw out key lessons learned and ensure that the project fits well with current 
directions and projects of the Department of Education, with the support of a 
consultant  e-learning  or  education  specialist  recruited  by  the  SAS  (terms  of 
reference to be drafted by SAS and approved by ADB). 
(iii)  Recruit a reading specialist consultant to develop an online training program that 
is correct in terms of reading principles and consistent with the SAS teacher 
training program (terms of reference to be drafted by SAS and approved by ADB).

12  Appendix 3 
 
(iv)  Adapt the SAS teacher training curriculum from its current face-to-face form to an 
online format, with the support of a consultant instructional designer (terms of 
reference to be drafted by SAS and approved by ADB). 
(v)  Engage a software development consultant to develop software and the website 
for the teacher training program (terms of reference to be drafted by SAS and 
approved by ADB). 
(vi)  Establish the CAMP sites by purchasing and delivering appropriate computers, 
equipment, furniture, and software. 
(vii)  Ensure that BSP 
(a)  assigns a custodian at each site to make the computers available to 
teachers, and prepare and maintain the schedule of use of the computers 
for online teacher training; 
(b)  maintains the computers in good condition; 
(c)  continues to provide internet connections after the initial provision under 
the project expires; and 
(d)  provides information and communication technology training to teachers 
teaching in schools near the CAMP sites. 
(viii)  Cooperate  with  the  Department  of  Education  to  inform  teachers  about  the 
availability of the CAMP site training and the credits that can be earned upon 
completion of training. 
(ix)  Monitor the number of teachers enrolling and completing the online training, and 
respond to issues raised by participants and others. 
(x)  Ensure the timely introduction of the training program and provide online support 
to participating teachers as required. 
(xi)  Keep a register of teachers who successfully complete the program, so that they 
can be awarded credit from the Department of Education. 
(xii)  Monitor  and  reinforce  use  of  the  teaching  strategies  imparted  in  the  online 
training, assess other teaching strategies by engaging project monitors to visit 
schools  served  by  the  CAMP  site,  and  record  innovative  practices  for 
dissemination to other schools. 
(xiii)  Engage  an  independent  institution  to  design  the  monitoring  and  evaluation 
system, carry out some data collection, and conduct a baseline and impact study 
on the effectiveness of the online teacher training. 
(xiv)  Ensure that data is collected regularly and a feedback mechanism for continuous 
improvement of the training program is implemented. 
(xv)  Participate in a dissemination workshop or other activity in collaboration with the 
ADB Institute. 
 
D.  Reporting 
 
5.  SAS will produce an inception report and three milestone reports with financial reports, 
as well as short quarterly reports to keep ADB informed of project progress.  The payment 
milestones are as follows: 
 
(i)  Beginning year 1: 35% of contract amount. Inception report and detailed work 
plan. 
(ii)  End  year  1:  35%  of contract  amount.  Report  on  the  design  of  the  training 
program and baseline survey by independent institution. 
(iii)  End year 2: 25% of contract amount. Report on phase 1 and monitoring and 
evaluation report on the first 15 CAMP sites by independent institution. 
(iv)  End year 3: 5% of contract amount. Report on phases 2 and 3, and the final 
impact study from an independent institution.
